The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-Both these appeals are directed against the judgment of the High Court of Nagpur passed in an appeal under s. 19 1   f  of the Defence of India Act, 1939,

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 22, 1958 by Venkatarama Aiyar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. August 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-Both these appeals are directed against the judgment of the High Court of Nagpur passed in an appeal under s. 19 1   f  of the Defence of India Act, 1939, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Central Government requisitioned properties belonging to Hanskumar Kishanchand on February 19, 1941 under s.75A of Rules under Defence of India Act.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the power companyferred by s. 75 A  of the Rules framed under the Act, the Central Government requisitioned on February 19, 1941, certain properties belonging to Hanskumar Kishanchand, the appellant in Civil-Appeal No. 224 of 1954.

facts.text: No agreement on compensation amount, referred to Mr. Jafry, Additional District Judge, Khandwa under s.19(1)(b) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: As there was numberagreement on the amount of companypensation payable to him, the Central Government referred the determination thereof to Mr. Jafry, Additional District Judge, Khandwa, under s. 19 1   b  of the Act.

facts.text: Mr. Jafry awarded Rs. 13,000 as annual rent on March 31, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1943, Mr. Jafry pronounced his award, by which lie awarded a. sum of Rs. 13,000 as annual rent -for, the occupation of the premises.

facts.text: Appeal to High Court of Nagpur under s.19(1)(f), heard by Grille C.J. and Padhye J.

anchor.surface_text: Against this award, there was an appeal to the High Court of Nagpur under s. 19 1   f  of the Act, and that was heard by a Bench companysisting of Grille C. J. and Padhve J.

facts.text: Nagpur High Court judgment dated December 31, 1947 enhanced annual rent by Rs. 3,250 and allowed compensation for dislocation of High School.

anchor.surface_text: By their judgment dated December 31, 1947, they enhanced the annual rent payable to the appellant by a sum of Its. 3,250, and they also allowed certain other sums as companypensation for dislocation of the High School which 1180 was being run on the property.

facts.text: High School was being run on the property.

anchor.surface_text: and they also allowed certain other sums as companypensation for dislocation of the High School which 1180 was being run on the property. The appellant applied for leave to appeal against this judgment to the Federal Court under ss. 109 and I 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure in respect of the amounts disallowed.

facts.text: Appellant applied for leave to appeal to Federal Court under ss.109 and 110 CPC regarding disallowed amounts.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant applied for leave to appeal against this judgment to the Federal Court under ss. 109 and I 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure in respect of the amounts disallowed. A similar application was also filed by the Government with reference to the enhancement of companypensation.

facts.text: Government filed similar application for leave regarding enhancement.

anchor.surface_text: A similar application was also filed by the Government with reference to the enhancement of companypensation. On August 25, 1949, both these applications were granted, and a certificate was issued that the appeals fulfilled the requirements of ss. 109 and 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Leave to appeal granted on August 25, 1949 by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: On August 25, 1949, both these applications were granted, and a certificate was issued that the appeals fulfilled the requirements of ss. 109 and 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure. That is how the two appeals companye before us.

facts.text: Preliminary objection by Solicitor-General to maintainability of CA 224/54 on ground that High Court judgment under s.19(1)(f) is an award, not judgment/decree/order under ss.109/110 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: At the opening of the hearing, a preliminary objection was taken by the learned Solicitor-General to the maintainability of Civil Appeal No. 224 of 1954 on the ground that the judgment of the High Court passed in appeal under s. 19 1   f  was an award and number a judgment, decree or order within the meaning of ss. 109 and 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure,

facts.text: If objection correct, CA 225/54 also incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: and that accordingly the appeal was incompetent. If this companytention is right, Civil Appeal No. 225 of 1954 preferred by the Government would also be incompetent.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed both appeals as incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we dismiss both the appeals as incompetent.

issues.text: Whether the judgment of the High Court passed in appeal under s. 19(1)(f) of the Defence of India Act, 1939 is an award and not a judgment, decree or order within the meaning of ss. 109 and 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure making the appeal incompetent?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Achbru Ram, learned counsel for the appellant does number dispute that the proceedings under s. 19 1   b  are by way of arbitration, but he companytends that when once the matter companyes before the High Court by way of appeal under s. 19 1  f , it becomes a civil proceeding under the ordinary jurisdiction of the Court, and that any decision therein is open to appeal under ss. 109 and I 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure. He further companytends that even apart from those provisions, the appeal was companypetent under Cl. 29 of the Letters Patent

holdings.text: An appeal to the High Court under s.19(1)(f) of the Defence of India Act comes before it not as a Court but as an arbitrator or persona designata.

anchor.surface_text: The principles being thus well-settled, we have to see in the present case whether an appeal to the High Court under s. 19 1  f  of the Act comes before it as a Court or as arbitrator. Under s. 19 1  b , the reference is admittedly to an arbitrator.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reference under s.19(1)(b) to arbitrator; s.19(1)(f) appeal construed as to designated authority not Court; retains arbitration character as continuation.

holdings.text: An appeal under s.19(1)(f) is of the nature of arbitration proceedings and the decision given therein is an award.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether an appeal under s. 19 1  f  is of the nature of arbitration proceedings, and whether the decision given therein is an award came up directly for consideration in Kollegal Silk Filatures Ltd. v. Province of Madras

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeal is continuation of original arbitration; proceeding retains character; agrees with Kollegal Silk Filatures precedent.

holdings.text: The decision of the High Court in the appeal under s.19(1)(f) is not a judgment, decree or order either within ss.109 and 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure or cl.29 of the Letters Patent of the Nagpur High Court; the present appeals are incompetent.

precedents.case_name: National Telephone Company Limited v. Postmaster-General
precedents.cited_proposition: Reference to an established Court imports ordinary incidents of procedure and right of appeal.
precedents.cited_holding: When a question is stated to be referred to an established Court without more, it, iii my opinion, imports that the ordinary incidents of the procedure of that Court are to attach, and also that any general right of appeal from its decision likewise attaches.
